title: AfterPay denies being a sitting duck for regulators
text:
AfterPay Touch has dismissed claims it is a sitting duck for regulatory action saying it is not currently the subject of any review and is looking forward to contributing to broad based review of the payments industry in 2020.

The buy-now-pay-later juggernaut with a market cap of $7.5 billion also categorically rejected assertions the company’s business model hurts retailers who use the service, saying Afterpay generates business and helps them access markets difficult youth segments.

“Afterpay is not currently subject to an RBA [Reserve Bank of Australia inquiry or review process. We welcome the opportunity to engage with the RBA as part of its broad-based, periodic review of the payments industry next year,” the company said in a statement.

AfterPay Touch hit the headlines again last week after the research team from UBS initiated coverage on the stock with a sell rating, forecasting that the share price would halve over the next 12 months as the company and its business model faced scrutiny from regulators here and abroad.

The company does not charge its customers interest - only late fees – and is not captured by consumer credit laws in Australia. The vast bulk of the company’s revenue is earned from merchant fees or from the retailers who use the service.

The public rebuttal of UBS comes hard on the heels of several days of intense media scrutiny of the divisive company.
description: AfterPay Touch has dismissed claims it is a sitting duck for regulatory action saying it looks forward to contributing to a broad based review of the payments industry in 2020.
